Planned Giving Day of Giving Named Endowed Funds Make a Gift About Us Hopkins School is a premier independent, gender-inclusive day school for students in grades 7-12. Our students are curious— they love to think and learn. Here each day, at the nation’s third oldest independent school, high achieving students come to learn with an intellectual passion, inspiring and challenging one another in a collective pursuit of excellence. The Hopkins program can be demanding, but the culture of the school is also caring and supportive. Hopkins School hires passionate teachers who know their subjects well, and who bring a passion for teaching and mentoring young people. If you like to think, if you’re passionate about learning, this is the place for you. Hopkins at a Glance Faculty and Staff Our Head of School Employment Opportunities Community Safety Mission and History Equity and Community Contact Us Our Strategic Plan Committee of Trustees 986 Forest Road New Haven, Connecticut 06515 (203) 397-1001 Nondiscrimination Policy Privacy Policy Voted #1 Best Day School in CT, 2024 Hopkins is a private middle school and high school for grades 7-12. Located on a campus overlooking New Haven, CT, the School takes pride in its intellectually curious students as well as its dedicated faculty and staff.

About Us | Hopkins House Skip to content About Us Programs News & Events News Events Get Involved Join Our Team About Us Programs News & Events News Events Get Involved Join Our Team Donate Now Search About Us Programs News & Events News Events Get Involved Join Our Team Donate Now Search About Us Our History Founded in 1939, Hopkins House is a nonprofit learning center for children, youth, and families, named in memory of Dr. J. Milton Hopkins, an African American physician who practiced in Alexandria, Virginia until his death at the age of 52 in 1927. Graduates of Hopkins House programs include a former Mayor of the City of Alexandria, Circuit Court Judge, Army General, Hollywood musician, and other achievers. Click Here To Read More History >>> Our Mission The mission of Hopkins House is to provide high quality, high impact educational programs and learning opportunities to children, youth, and their families, regardless of income, to help them achieve, in measurably effective ways, their full intellectual, economic, and social potential. The Community We Serve Hopkins House serves a socially diverse community of working and military families in the Northern Virginia metropolitan area. All programs are open to the public regardless of income or residency. Senior Managers J. Glenn Hopkins Chief Executive Officer Mr. Hopkins joined the staff in 1991. He is the seventh and longest-serving chief executive of Hopkins House. He has a master’s degree from Columbia University in the City of New York. He has over 35 years of senior-level management experience. He is a resident of the Fairfax County, Virginia. Garvey Wright Vice President & Chief Operating Officer Mr. Wright joined the staff in 2020. He is a military veteran, having served in the United States Army for over 30 years managing hundreds of millions of dollars in financial transactions and contracts. He has a bachelor’s degree from Virginia State University. He is a resident of Fairfax County, Virginia. Mohammad Hossain Assistant Vice President & Chief Financial Officer Mr. Hossain joined the staff in 2020, as Staff Accountant. He was promoted to Director, Finance & Operations in 2021, and to Chief Operating in 2023. He has master’s degrees in business administration and in finance. He is a resident of Fairfax County, Virginia. Stephanie Turner-Menson Director, Early Childhood Learning Institute Ms. Turner-Menson joined the staff in 2007. She has a bachelor’s degree from Strayer University and over 16 years of professional experience in management and education. She previously served as Principal of Hopkins House’s Innovative Preschool Academy in Herndon, Virginia (now closed). She is a resident of Fairfax County, Virginia. Brandon Peel Principal, James L & Juliette McNeil Preschool Academy Mr. Peel joined Hopkins House in 2025. He previously taught in D.C. Public Schools before relocating to Europe to play professional basketball. While abroad, he earned a master’s degree in media and communication Industries from the University of East London. He is a resident of Prince George’s County, Maryland. Justin Thomas Principal, Helen Day Preschool Academy Dr. Thomas joined the staff in 2025. He holds a Ph.D. in Educational Leadership from the University of Houston – Clear Lake and has over 16 years of professional experience in management and education. Dr. Thomas is a resident of the District of Columbia. Cheryl Butler Director, Student Recruitment & Scholarship Fund Ms. Butler joined the staff in 2022. She has a master’s degree from Howard University and over 12 years of professional experience in management and education, most recently working for Arlington Public Schools and is a resident of the District of Columbia. Board of Trustees Hopkins House is governed by its Board of Trustees, composed of distinguished individuals elected by the Hopkins House Community Stakeholders (i.e., donors of $100 or more) to serve 2-year terms (i.e., “Class”). The trustees meet quarterly and govern the affairs of the Organization through its policy committees, which meet monthly. James L. Banks, Jr. Board Chair, Class of 2026 Mr. Banks has been a Hopkins House Trustee since 2016. He is General Counsel for the Society for Human Resource Management. He holds a Juris Doctor degree from University of Virginia. He is a resident of Potomac Falls, Virginia, and Chair of the Trustees Executive Committee and ex officio member of all other Trustee committees. Harry “Bud” Hart Board Vice Chair, Class of 2026 Mr. Hart has been a Hopkins House Trustee since 1986. He is Managing Partner at the law firm of Hart, Calley, Gibbs, & Karp, P.C. He holds a Juris Doctor degree from Georgetown University. He is a resident of Alexandria, Virginia. Bud is a member of the Trustees’ Executive Committee. Elizabeth Partoyan Board Secretary, Class of 2027 Ms. Partoyan has been a Hopkins House Trustee since 2010. She is a resident of the City of Alexandria, Virginia, senior fellow at the National League of Cities, and holds a master’s degree in educational psychology from Howard University. Elizabeth chairs the Trustees’ Programs & Assessment Committee and is a member of the Trustees’ Executive Committee. Jesse O’ Connell Board Treasurer, Class of 2026 Mr. O’Connell has been a Hopkins House Trustee since 2020. He is Chief Advancement Officer of the American Council on Education, holds a master’s degree from Georgetown University, resides in Alexandria, Virginia, and chairs the Trustees’ Budget & Personnel Policy Committee. Julie N. Jakopic Past Board Chair, Class of 2027 Ms. Jakopic has been a Hopkins House Trustee since 2002. She is President/CEO of iLead Strategies. A resident of the City of Alexandria, Virginia, she holds a master’s degree from the University of Maryland. Julie chairs the Trustees’ Public Policy & Advocacy Committee. J. Glenn Hopkins President Mr. Hopkins has been a Hopkins House Trustee since 1991. He is the seventh and longest-serving President of Hopkins House. He has a master’s degree from Columbia University in the City of New York. He is a resident of the Fairfax County, Virginia, and a member of the Trustees Executive Committee and ex officio member of all other Trustee committees. Shaun Amend Trustee, Class of 2026 Mr. Amend has been a Hopkins House Trustee since 2022. He is military operations analyst, resident of Dumfries, Virginia, father of a Hopkins House Preschool Academy alumna, U.S. Army Veteran, and Vice Chair of the Trustees’ Programs & Assessment Committee. Debra Arnett Trustee, Class of 2026 Ms. Arnett has been a Hopkins House Trustee since 2022. She is Director of Real Estate at Carr Real Estate Services, a resident of Fairfax County, Virginia, holds a bachelor’s degree from Christian Brothers University, and is a member of the Trustees’ Budget & Personnel Policy Committee. Beverly Barr Trustee, Class of 2026 Ms. Barr has been a Hopkins House Trustee since 2010. She is a resident of Prince William County, Virginia, Ms. Barr holds a bachelor’s degree in business and human resources from Strayer University. Beverly chairs the Trustees’ Scholarships & Recognitions Committee. Helen Clemens Trustee, Class of 2026 Ms. Clemens has been a Hopkins House Trustee since 2022. She is Assistant City Attorney at the City of Alexandria, Virginia. A resident of Alexandria, Virginia, she is the parent of a Hopkins House Preschool Academy Young Scholar and holds a Juris Doctor degree from George Washington Law School. Helen is a member of the Trustees’ Public Policy & Advocacy Committee. Jahreem P. Edwards Trustee, Class of 2027 Mr. Edwards is Vice President and Business Banking Relationship Manager at M&T Bank. A resident of Upper Marlboro, Maryland, Mr. Edwards holds a bachelor’s degree from the University of Maryland. He is a member of the Hopkins House Budget & Personnel Policy Committee. Charniele Herring Trustee, Class of 2027 The Honorable Herring has been a Hopkins House Trustee since 2009. She is a State Delegate representing the 46th District in the Virginia House of Delegates and Vice President of Administrative & Logistics Services, Inc. A resident of the City of Alexandria, Delegate Herring holds a J.D. degree from the Catholic University of America, Columbus School of Law. Robert D. Hicks Trustee, Class of 2026 Mr. Hicks has been a Hopkins House Trustee since 1999. Now retired, he was formerly a teacher with Alexandria City Public Schools. A resident of Falls Church, Virginia, Mr. Hicks holds a master’s degree from Virginia State University. Robert is a member of the Trustees’ Scholarships & Recognitions Committee. Jeanne Williams Trustee, Class of 2027 Ms. Williams is a fashion and marketing entrepreneur. A resident of Fairfax County, Virginia, Ms. Williams holds a master’s degree from Southern New Hampshire University. She is a former President of the Hopkins House James L & Juliette McNeil Preschool Academy Parents Council and a member of the Hopkins House Programs & Assessment Committee. Search Home City Government Committees & Boards Committees & Boards Board Structure Duties Vacancies Board of Appeals Location / Date TBD • 5 members • Experience with building and property maintenance • At-large To hear appeals of decisions made by the Building Official 0 Community Redevelopment Agency Meets every other month; 1st Thursday 3 PM Building Department Conference Room • Five elected City Council members and two appointed volunteer members • …Must reside or be engaged in business within the area of operation of the agency, which shall be coterminous with the area of operation of the county or municipality… • Carry out activities within the CRA area; developing budgets, creating contracts with service providers, implementing elements of the CRA master plan and approving CRA related expenses 0 Economic Development Advisory Committee Meets 3rd Wednesday each month 5 PM Community Development Conference Room • Must be registered voter Osceola County • Must meet one or more of the following: 1) Resident of the City of St. Cloud 2) Own real property within the City of St. Cloud 3) Own and operate a business with a business location within the City of St. Cloud • Provide the City Manager and City Council with business related recommendations on sustaining, generating and developing economic growth within the City of St. Cloud 0 Finance Committee Meets quarterly (January, April, July, and October); 4th Tuesday 6 PM Council Chambers •	Members must be city residents •	Five voting members – coterminous with Council terms •	Make recommendations to the City Council regarding budgets, debt service, financial policies, and capital expenditures •	Review the fiscal activities of the City 0 General Employee Pension Board of Trustees Meets quarterly; 2nd Tuesday 1:30 PM City Hall Bldg A -  DRC Conference Room •	Seven voting members •	Three members are appointed by City Council;  four members are elected by employees •	Oversee the asset management of the General Employee Pension Funds 0 Historic Preservation Board Meets 1st Tuesday of every other month 6 PM Council Chambers • Seven voting members and two alternates appointed by Council • Preference to individuals who reside or have principal place of business in City of St. Cloud • Members chosen from among disciplines of architecture, archaeology history, architectural history, landscape architecture, construction, construction management, engineering, planning, general contractor, commercial development, real estate, banking or law • Reviews all changes to historically significant structures within the historic district. Holds public hearings and issues Certificates of Appropriateness. • Coordinates with the State of Florida’s Division of Historical Resources Certified Local Government program • Collaborates with the St. Cloud Main Street organization and any other organization to inform and educate citizens concerning the historic, cultural, archaeological and architectural heritage of the City 2 Planning Commission Meets 3rd Tuesday each month; 6:00 PM Council Chambers •	Five voting members and two alternates •	Members cannot serve on the Zoning Board of Adjustment simultaneously •	Members must be city residents and registered voters – Non coterminous with Council terms •	Act in an advisory capacity to the City Council relating to zoning, land use, and the Comprehensive Plan 0 Police and Firefighters Pension Board of Trustees Meets quarterly; 3rd Tuesday 4:00 PM City Hall Bldg A -  DRC Conference Room •	Five voting members •	Two members are appointed by Council; one by the Fire Department,  one by the Police Department and one is Board appointed •	Oversee the asset management of the Police Department and Fire Department pension funds 0 Recreation Advisory Committee Meets 3rd Wednesday each month; 5:30 PM Civic Center •	Five voting members, coterminous with Council terms. •	Two alternate members with 1 year calendar terms •	No more than 2 voting members can be County residents. •	Alternates move into vacancies of regular seats except at expiration of terms. •	Work in cooperation with the Parks and Recreation Department to plan and implement programs and facilities for all residents 1 Veterans Council NOTE: Applications to this board are accepted only if appointed by City Council 0 Zoning Board of Adjustment Meets 2nd Wed. each month 6:30 PM Council Chambers • Members cannot serve on the Planning Commission simultaneously • Members must be city residents and registered voters • Five voting members and two alternates – Non coterminous with Council terms • Grant variances • Perform the administrative review • Reverse the decisions of the Building Official as it relates to zoning codes 0 To apply, click the name of the board / committee to complete the online application.  Interested in applying? Anthony Hopkins: Biography, Actor, Movies, Age & Family Search Newsletter History - Culture Musicians Athletes Movies - TV Artists Power - Politics Business Scientists Scholars - Educators Activists True Crime BIO Buys Privacy Notice Terms Of Use Skip to Content History & Culture Musicians Athletes Movies & TV Newsletter Charlie Sheen’s Addiction Kathy Bates Almost Quit Emmy Nominee Owen Wilson Shohei Ohtani Real-Life Heroes of 9/11 Famous Actors Anthony Hopkins Anthony Hopkins Anthony Hopkins is an Oscar-winning actor known for roles in many films, including 'The Lion in Winter,' 'Silence of the Lambs' and 'The Remains of the Day.' By Biography.com Editors Updated: Apr 10, 2024 4:44 PM EDT Photo: Gabriel Grams/FilmMagic // Getty Images We may earn commission from links on this page, but we only recommend products we back. (1937-) Jump to: Who Is Anthony Hopkins? Quick Facts Early Life and Acting Career Movies Personal Life Alcoholism Who Is Anthony Hopkins? Anthony Hopkins pursued a stage career before working in film in the late 1960s. Known for a variety of projects ranging from The Dawning to The Remains of the Day to Amistad , Hopkins has been nominated for several Oscars, winning for The Silence of the Lambs and The Father . His more fantastical work includes Titus , The Mask of Zorro and Thor, as well as Westworld. Quick Facts FULL NAME: Philip Anthony Hopkins BORN: December 31, 1937 BIRTHPLACE: Margam, Port Talbot, Wales SPOUSE: Stella Arroyave (m. 2003), Jennifer Lynton (m. 1973–2002), Petronella Barker (m. 1966–1972) CHILDREN: Abigail Hopkins ASTROLOGICAL SIGN: Capricorn Early Life and Acting Career Philip Anthony Hopkins was born on December 31, 1937, in Margam, Port Talbot, Wales. Hopkins is the son of Muriel Yeats — a distant relative of the Irish poet William Butler Yeats — and Richard Hopkins. His early years in Wales and schooling at Cowbridge Grammar School were relatively unremarkable, but when the soon-to-be actor met Richard Burton , the course of his life would dramatically change. Encouraged and inspired by Burton, Hopkins enrolled at the Royal Welsh College of Music and Drama when he was only 15 years old. After graduation in 1957, Hopkins spent two years in the British Army before moving to London to begin training at the Royal Academy of Dramatic Art. After training and working for several years, he became a kind of protégé of the legendary actor Sir Laurence Olivier . In 1965 Olivier invited Hopkins to join the Royal National Theatre and become his understudy. The famed actor wrote in his memoir, "A new young actor in the company of exceptional promise named Anthony Hopkins was understudying me and walked away with the part of Edgar like a cat with a mouse between its teeth." When Olivier came down with appendicitis during a production called Dance of Death , the young Hopkins stepped in, making waves with his performance. Billed as Olivier's heir to the British acting throne, Hopkins had the momentum to make the leap from stage to film, which was his primary ambition. He started on the small screen in 1967 with a BBC production of A Flea in Her Ear . Soon after he was cast in The Lion in Winter (1968) as Richard I, sharing the screen with established stars Peter O'Toole and Katharine Hepburn . Throughout the 1970s, Hopkins continued to work in film and on stage, garnering critical attention for this double duty. He starred in a Broadway production of Peter Shaffer's Equus (1974) even as he devoted more and more attention to developing his talents for television and film. His method of preparation for roles has always been a source of fascination for critics and young actors alike. Hopkins prefers to memorize his lines in extremis, sometimes repeating them more than 200 times. The finished product typically reveals a naturalness that skillfully hides the massive amount of rehearsal the actor has done. Because of this style, Hopkins prefers fewer, more spontaneous takes, and has occasionally butted heads with directors who he perceives as deviating from the script too much or demanding too many takes. He has noted in the past that once he says a line and is done with a take, he forgets that line forever. Movies Hopkins' career began heating up in the 1970s and '80s. He won an Emmy  for his role as Bruno Richard Hauptmann in The Lindbergh Kidnapping Case (1976).  Throughout the 1980s, Hopkins continued to impress the critics with his  work in film and TV, winning multiple Emmy Awards and a BAFTA Award. 'The Silence of the Lambs' as Hannibal Lecter In  1989, Hopkins returned to the stage for a production of the musical drama M.  Butterfly . But it was in 1991 that Hopkins, now well into his fifties,  finally found himself shot to superstardom. His unforgettable, 17-minute  performance as the infamous psychopath Hannibal Lecter in The Silence of the  Lambs frightened and wowed fans and critics alike. At the time he took  the role, Hopkins had been considering giving up on movies and retiring  to London for a career on the stage. The fortuitous role resulted in not  only an Oscar but a distinguished place in the popular consciousness as  perhaps the most memorable on-screen villain of all time. 'The Remains of the Day' Hopkins has since played the role again in the film's sequels. On the heels of his first  real Hollywood blockbuster, Hopkins wisely chose to follow up with his  film The Remains of the Day (1993), for which he was nominated for  another Academy Award. He would be nominated again for Nixon (1995) and Amistad (1997). In 1993 Hopkins was knighted by the British Empire. In April 2000, he became a naturalized citizen of the United States and, in 2006, he was awarded the Golden Globes' Cecil B. DeMille Award for lifetime achievement. 'Hitchcock' The acclaimed actor continued to work in major motion pictures, appearing in such films as Proof (2005), Beowulf (2007) and Thor (2011). Cast as famed horror movie director Alfred Hitchcock in the 2012 biopic Hitchcock , Hopkins earned raves for his starring role in the film, alongside Helen Mirren as Hitchcock's wife, Alma Reville. The movie explores the making of the director's horror classic Psycho . 'Westworld,' 'The Two Popes,' 'The Father' Hopkins played the biblical character Methuselah in Noah (2014) and also appeared in Transformers: The Last Knight (2017) as Sir Edmund Burton. On the small screen, he's also found interesting characters to play, specifically on HBO's sci-fi thriller Westworld , as AI mastermind Robert Ford. Following its premiere in 2016, the show became one of the most-watched dramas among the network's original programming and has won multiple Emmys. Back on the big screen, Hopkins in 2019 starred as Pope Benedict XVI , alongside Jonathan Pryce as the future Pope Francis , in The Two Popes . He then delivered another powerful performance as a man battling dementia in The Father (2020), opposite fellow Oscar winner Olivia Colman , for which he was nominated for several awards. Hopkins won the Oscar for Best Actor for his role. Personal Life In 2003, Hopkins married his third wife, antique dealer Stella Arroyave, who hails from Colombia. He was previously married to Jennifer Lynton, from 1973 to 2002, and before that had been married to Petronella Barker, from 1967 to 1972. He and Barker had one daughter, Abigail Hopkins, who was born in 1968. Alcoholism The actor has long battled alcoholism, once saying, "I led a pretty self-destructive life for a few decades. It was only after I put my demons behind me that I was able to fully enjoy acting." In 1975, Hopkins began attending Alcoholics Anonymous and working to put those demons behind him. Fact Check: We strive for accuracy and fairness. If you see something that doesn't look right, contact us ! QUOTES I don't know what  acting is, but I enjoy it. I led a pretty self-destructive life for a few decades. It was  only  after I put my demons behind me that I was able to fully enjoy  acting. That is why we provide the highest quality care available for your pet in a compassionate and nurturing environment. Our veterinarians recognize your role and commitment to your pet’s health and strive to create a health regimen designed specifically for you and your pet’s needs. Our History Highland Park Animal Hospital was founded by Dr. Alton Hopkins and opened its doors to the public on June 23, 1964 with the goal of becoming and staying an integral part of the Highland Park community by providing outstanding veterinary care, as well as providing support to underserved dogs and cats via our non-profit, the Hard Luck Hound Society . Canine Country Club was created and opened in 2000. We are a Heritage Veterinary Practice according to The American Veterinary Medical History Society because we have been in continuous operation for over 50 years. Who We Are Simply put, we know how important your pets are to you and your family. Our mission at Highland Park Animal Hospital is to provide the highest quality care available for your pet in a compassionate and nurturing environment. Our veterinarians recognize your role and commitment to your pet’s health and strive to create a health regimen designed specifically for you and your pet’s needs. Many of our team members are Fear Free Certified. Dallas pet owners have many choices today when choosing veterinary care for their dog or cat. We take pride in providing personalized pet care that is more than just a laundry list method of treatment. Our Services At Highland Park Animal Hospital we offer traditional veterinary services as well as advanced services including cold laser therapy , ultrasonography , in-house lab work , and several additional areas of specialized surgeries such as soft tissue repairs, mass removals, splenectomies and orthopedic procedures such as FHO’s (femoral head ostectomy) and TPLO’s (tibial plateau leveling osteotomy). At Canine Country Club we offer a luxury boarding experience for both dogs and cats at our Dallas location's Urban Oasis . Dogs can also choose to enjoy a different style of boarding at our Ranch Retreat location in Ennis, Texas. Our team of professional pet stylists are also on staff to work with each client on their specific grooming needs. We are strategically located off of North Central Expressway in Dallas near Highland Park in a three story, state-of-the-art-building with plenty of parking. Want to see more of Highland Park and Canine Country Club? Check out our Virtual Tour . Our Dallas Community The Dallas, Texas community is one that we are passionate about. About Us – Hopkins Real Estate MENU HOME ABOUT US DEVELOPMENT BROKERAGE NEWS CONTACT About Us Hopkins Real Estate About Us About Us Tom October 24, 2014 June 10, 2022 Hopkins Real Estate (“HRE”) is a private real estate development company based in Irvine California led by industry veteran Stephen Hopkins.   The company operates as a full-service development organization, specializing in the development, redevelopment, ownership, and leasing of retail and mixed use properties located in in-fill locations throughout California. Steve Hopkins has developed and/or redeveloped nearly 100 projects encompassing over 9 million square feet of gross leaseable area since 1972. The Company’s established presence in California and reputation for sourcing unique opportunities, especially in in-fill locations, through their unparalleled relationships has made them one of the foremost retail development firms in the region. Due to their focus on relationships, Hopkins Real Estate has the distinctive ability to secure deals through a wide variety of channels including long-standing, deep ties to the real estate brokerage and local communities and municipalities. Throughout the test of time, these relationships have given HREG numerous “first-look” opportunities directly from retailers, brokers, property owners, and former city consultants, often times, circumventing the RFQ process. In addition to existing relationships, the Company’s deep bench of talented development professionals actively seeks out attractive opportunities. Steve Hopkins Steve Hopkins is the CEO of Hopkins Real Estate Group and heads up the development business.  Steve started his real estate career with Coldwell Banker in 1968. He is the founder of Hopkins Development Company, the predecessor of HRE, in 1972. Over the years Steve has developed over 100 projects and over 9.1 million square feet of commercial real estate. Steve remains very active in several professional associations. He is a Trustee for the International Council of Shopping Centers, is on the Advisory Board of the California Business Properties Association, is involved with the Urban Land Institute as a Council Member and is a member of the Community Redevelopment Association. Steve is one of the pioneers of urban in-fill development and public/private partnerships with municipalities. Steve was born in Los Angeles and grew up in Long Beach, California. He graduated from UCLA with a Bachelor of Arts degree in Business Administration. Steve has four children and lives in Newport Beach, California. Tom Nguyen, Esq Tom Nguyen is the President of HRE and heads up its brokerage business.  Tom Nguyen started his career in as a real estate attorney but quickly transitioned over to a full time commercial real estate broker.  Tom was most recently an Executive Vice President at NAI Capital where he founded and headed up its Pacific Rim Division where he was consistently a top producer. Over the years Tom has transacted almost every product type - from retail and office to multifamily and development land totalling nearly 1 billion in deals.  The majority of his work involves acquisitions, dispositions, and portfolio management for high net worths, family offices, and institutions.  With over 20 years of experience representing clients as well as a principal, Tom can add value to any commercial real estate scenario. Within the past 5 years, Tom has acted a principal investor and specialist in “horizontal development” where he acquires value added land and either sells or assigns the land to residential or industrial developers who builds or goes “vertical.”  Within the last four years, Tom has acted as a principal in the acquisition and assignment/or sale of over 90 million in land development projects. Tom grew up in Orange County and has a dual BA/BS from UCLA and a law degree from CWSOL in San Diego.  Aside from commercial real estate, Tom is an entrepreneur and investor in high performing restaurants and tech startups. Email Tom at tnguyen@hopkinsre.com Recent Transactions Rancho Brookhurst Center in Little Saigon acquired for $22.75 Million Little Saigon Property Sold for $15.5 Million Grocery Anchored Retail Center Acquired for $30 million 6 story Prime Medical Building for Sale - $21 million Fully Entitled 250+ townhome subdivision in Arcadia - Exclusive Listing for $60 million 144 Bed Senior Assisted Living Facility for Sale at $12.75 Million Previous Transactions (sample list) Represented the buyer in a Walmart Anchored Retail Center in Torrance for $55.5 Million Represented the buyer in 120,000 SF Multi-Tenant Industrial Park in Walnut, CA Represented Wing Lung Bank in lease of 16th floor of 520 Newport Center Dr Represented the Seller in an Office Campus on 3 acres of land in Costa Mesa, CA Represented the Seller in the sale of 3.9 acres of land in Santa Ana to home builder City Ventures Dean Isaacs Mr. Isaacs has over 30 years of experience in the retail and commercial real estate development industry, from both a retailer’s and developer’s perspective, while working on projects all over the Western U.S..  He has a long history of representing developers, landowners and cities in acquisition, entitlement, property management and development issues, and performing development management functions. His clients have included the City of Oakland’s Economic Development department and the Office of Neighborhood Investment, the Contra Costa Water District, the City of Rohnert Park, Goodwill Industries, Sand Hill Property Company (development management on a $321M+ mixed-use project – “Main Street Cupertino”), Warmington Homes, Compass Acquisition Partners, Clark Realty Capital, Arcadia Development Co., ICI Development Company, Diversified Investment & Management, and Pacific Union Commercial, working on retail and mixed-use projects in Northern and Central California. He also manages and leases a 14-property Peninsula, East Bay and South Bay-based portfolio of retail, industrial and office properties for Prodesse Property Group. He was previously employed as Vice President of Development for General Growth Properties, responsible for all ground up development, remodels and renovations on Company-owned regional mall properties in California, Arizona and New Mexico, supervising a staff of seven developers. Prior to joining General Growth, Mr. Isaacs worked primarily on redevelopment projects in his career, necessitating constant interaction, and negotiation and teaming with local municipalities. He opened a regional office for Southern California-based Hopkins Real Estate Group, seeking development projects in Northern California, and assisted in the start-up of private development firm, Highland Development Company in San Mateo. At Highland, he was responsible for all shopping center development and redevelopment projects (in Sacramento, Manteca, Hanford, Phoenix, and Suisun City) from land acquisition through entitlement, major tenant leasing, construction and asset disposition, while overseeing the Company’s internal construction department. He has also been employed as a Regional Director for Burnham Pacific Properties (San Francisco, a public REIT) with responsibility for all ground up and value-added development, acquisitions and construction in the Northern California, Northern Nevada and Utah region, and as a real estate manager responsible for new store locations throughout California for both Ralphs Grocery Company and Costco Wholesale Corp. While with Burnham Pacific Properties, he was responsible for all aspects of the 355,000SF Downtown Pleasant Hill project, a mixed-use retail, hotel and residential public/private partnership project, among other projects in Richmond and Cameron Park. A graduate of the University of California at Los Angeles with a Bachelor’s Degree in History, Mr. Isaacs also holds a Juris Doctorate from Southwestern University School of Law. He is a licensed California Real Estate Broker. Mr. Isaacs’ professional memberships include the International Council of Shopping Centers (Northern California Program Committee member, 1994-2000 and 2007 to the present), the Municipal Management Association of Northern California (“MMANC” - 2011-present) and the San Francisco Planning and Urban Research Association (SPUR). Search Popular Searches Fastrack Rides & Attractions Map Contact Us Contact Us Toggle Navigation Customer Services Local Residents Lost Property SignLive Contact Us Customer Services Local Residents Lost Property SignLive We're here to help Our friendly and knowledgeable team at Thorpe Park would love to answer your questions regarding any aspect of your trip. We are on hand to deal with any ticket enquiry or to help you plan your day and answer any questions that you may have prior to your thrilling visit to Thorpe Park. You can contact us in any of the below ways: Visit the help centre Check out the FAQ pages where answers to most questions can be found. Check out our Help Centre first before contacting us - it's the best place to get the help you need! Help Centre Amending Your Booking Use your booking portal which allows you to amend the dates of your tickets without contacting us. If you still need support in changing your ticket date, get in contact with our team and we can support you. Booking Portal Live Chat Thorpe Park's Digital Assistant is on hand to help you with any enquiries. Our agents are online daily from 9:30am - 4:30pm, or until half an hour before the park closes should you require further assistance. Outside of these hours, you will only be able to contact the Thorpe Bot. To start a chat, click the blue chat icon in the bottom right corner of the page Guest Enquiries If you need to send us and email with a question, you can use our enquiry form. Please remember to check our FAQs first as this is often the faster way to find out the information you need. Average Response Time: 3 Days Contact Form Telephone You can contact our call centre team on 01932 577131 Our agents are on hand to answer your call from 09:30am  - 16:00pm Monday to Friday. We can still be reached via Live Chat or email, for any assistance you may need outside of these times. Want to talk about something specific? Our dedicated teams are also available to help you with the below areas: Guest Feedback We understand the importance of guest feedback and we are keen to hear about your experience. We rely on guests reporting their experience to us to ensure we are always under continuous improvement. Average Response Time: 3 days Contact Customer Services Lost Property If you have a lost item whilst at the park, you can raise a claim with our friends at Boomerang. Visit our Lost Property page for more information and next steps on how to report your missing items(s). Lost Property School Bookings You can visit our dedicated Schools page for all information on organising a school trip with us, prices & planning, resources, and more. Find out more Overnight Stays If you have a query about your overnight stay, check out our Frequently Asked Questions. For anything that can't be answered here, please contact our team on shark.hotel@thorpe-park.co.uk Overnight Stays FAQs VIP Experiences To discuss a new or existing VIP package please email the VIP team on vip@thorpe-park.co.uk Email VIP Experiences Corporate Events To enquire or to book a corporate event, please contact our events team on events@thorpe-park.co.uk Email Corporate Events Charity Requests Here at Thorpe Park, we support Merlin's Magic Wand, which is a global children's charity that supports children facing challenges of serious illness, disability or adversity. For more information please see Merlin's Magic Wand . We often support charities and schools within the immediate locality of the park. Due to numerous requests, only registered charities and schools based within the local vicinity of the park will be considered. Please email all requests through to charity.requests@thorpe-park.co.uk . Please note that we are unable to accept or respond to letter requests unless an email address is given. As we receive many requests each day, we cannot respond to them all. If you have not heard from us within 2 weeks, then we regret to inform you that your request has been unsuccessful. Claims Notification Enquiries The UK Employers Liability Insurance Policy and the Global Public Liability Insurance Policy are both held with Chubb European Group Limited under Policy Number UKCANC33447. Claims are administered by Mclarens and should be submitted via the claims portal. The portal ID is D00029. 2 locals on Park Board's short list Local News Sports Opinion NKY Things To Do Advertise Obituaries eNewspaper Legals NEWS 2 locals on Park Board's short list Mark Wert mwert@enquirer.com The panel searching for a new Cincinnati Parks director got a list of finalists Wednesday. It now must decide which of the 12 it wants to interview. The city's Board of Park Commissioners is seeking a replacement for longtime Director Willie Carden, who is eligible to retire June 1. Dianne Rosenberg, the park board president, hopes to have the replacement named before Carden's departure. The finalists for the job, which will have an annual salary of $155,000, are: Chandra Brown, the Cincinnati Public Schools' budget director Peter Bratt, a manager for the Dallas parks department John Deatrick, the leader of The Banks and streetcar projects Yvette Hartsfield, former parks and recreation director for Yonkers, New York Cordell Hopkins, a former area manager for the Chicago Parks District Clisby Jennelle, the CFO for the West Virginia Division of Natural Resources, Parks and Recreation Keith McClintock, former vice president of the Western Reserve Land Conservancy in northeast Ohio Steve Messerli, former director of two suburban Chicago county parks districts Todd Reese, parks and grounds superintendent for Oklahoma City Jeremy Rogers, the parks and recreation director for Kansas City, Kansas, and Wyandotte County Ryan Smith, the former event operations director of Kansas City's Arrowhead Stadium Wade Walcutt, parks and recreation director for Greensboro, North Carolina A review of the 75 resumes received by GovHR USA, the suburban Chicago search firm hired by the Park Board to help find a new director, shows that 34 of the 63 candidates that didn't make the finalist list had neither parks nor governmental experience. Another six had governmental experience, but not in parks. No Cincinnati or Hamilton County parks employees applied. In addition to placing ads in journals and websites for parks professionals, the consultant looked for and attempted to recruit candidates from park systems with the Gold Medal designation, said Charles Balling, a GovHR vice president. It's awarded in an annual program run by the American Academy for Park and Recreation Administration and the National Recreation and Park Association. Cincinnati's parks won such a gold medal in 1971; its recreation department took the medal in 1997. Rosenberg, who is leading the search panel, noted that the search firm had canvassed more than 40 stakeholders in January before the firm created and posted a list of 13 qualifications and 13 attributes sought in candidates. A list of the contacted stakeholders included current and former park commissioners, city administrators, Mayor John Cranley and City Council members, parks staff, Cincinnati Parks Foundation staff and board members, plus Hamilton County parks Director Jack Sutton, Cincinnati Center City Development Corp. chief Steve Leeper, four members of individual park advisory councils and three other parks advocates. Searches for two other high-profile local public jobs – for a new city fire chief and a new Cincinnati Public Schools superintendent – include using websites to gather public comments on what qualities that the public wants for those new leaders. The director search committee previously had held one meeting at the private Queen City Club and used the telephone on other occasions to talk business. Ohio laws require a government meeting be held in a place where members of the public and the media may attend. A reporter from The Enquirer attended Wednesday's meeting. Heidi Voorhees, a co-owner of the search firm, told the committee that at least one person dropped out of consideration after learning that the applicant resumes had been made public at The Enquirer's request under the state's Open Records Act. "The public needs to know that," said Park Commissioner Susan Castellini, a member of the search panel. The park board is paying the search firm up to $40,000 for its work. CHANGES AHEAD? Cincinnati Parks officials, responding to a recent critical state audit, could soon adopt a better way to keep its books and reach an agreement among the city, the parks and the Cincinnati Parks Foundation on various issues, including bidding and procurement. Park Board President Dianne Rosenberg told a City Council committee Tuesday that converting the parks to a double-entry accounting system would not require hiring additional staff and therefore could be done sooner than first thought. Parks officials previously had said shifting to the new system, already used by other city departments as a check on the movement of money, couldn't happen until the 2019 fiscal year. Adopting a double-entry system, which Rosenberg called "the standard" for such work, would be on the agenda for the board's April meeting, the board president said. The shift was called for in a 2016 external audit of the parks, in the wake of Enquirer reporting about Park Board procedures and practices, including an inappropriate $200,000 campaign donation for a proposed parks levy voters ultimately turned down in 2015. A state audit last month concurred in the need for a double-entry system. City Manager Harry Black last year had been trying to work out an agreement with the Park Board that would require that the department transfer any money it planned to spend on the park system into the city’s financial system, as every other city department does. Black wanted the city to be sure all of the money spent by the board follows bidding and procurement laws. The move also would curb the use of master service agreements instead of bidding to award contracts, as was done for millions of dollars in work at Smale Riverfront Park. Talks for an agreement broke down over Park Board members' concern they would lose control over nine endowments benefitting the parks for which they serve as trustees. Rosenberg spoke to the council Audit and Rules Committee after interrupting a meeting with Mayor John Cranley and other city officials on reaching an agreement. She told the committee that talks were proceeding, but that an agreement wasn't imminent.
